awd_titl_txt: OCE-PRF Track 2 (International): Towards a 3-Dimensional Understanding of the Meridional Overturning Circulation
awd_abstract_narration:
The "global meridional overturning circulation" is an ocean current that brings warm, often salty water from the tropics to the colder polar regions. This circulation acts to redistribute heat around the globe and has a profound influence of the Earth's climate, and for this reason is sometimes called the "global ocean conveyor belt." The Southern Ocean, which encircles the Antarctic continent, exerts a strong influence on the global overturning. However, in the Southern Ocean, the dynamics of this current are very poorly understood. In this project, the fellow (Christopher Chapman) together with sponsoring scientist Jean-Baptiste Sallée, at LOCEAN-IPSL, Paris, will work towards understanding the role that large undersea topography and much smaller scale turbulent flows, called "eddies" play in global overturning using a mixture of simple ocean models; observations from oceanographic instruments; and sophisticated global climate models. Our results will help reduce uncertainties in projections of future climate change and will aid policy makers to understand the potential impacts of their decisions. 

The Southern Ocean strongly influences the global overturning circulation. It is in the Southern Ocean that cold, deep waters upwell to the surface, that surface buoyancy forcing and diapycnal mixing processes cause water mass transformations and where energetic baroclinic eddies act to oppose the general northward overturning circulation driven by wind forcing. However, a lack of observations in the region and the prohibitive expense of running large-scale eddy-resolving simulations has meant that the Southern Ocean overturning is poorly understood. In particular, most studies to date exploit the fact that the Southern Ocean currents are primarily zonally oriented to treat the MOC as a two dimensional system, ignoring variations with longitude. 

However, recent observations have shown that the Southern Ocean is not 2-dimensional. Turbulence, tracer-mixing and water-mass subduction are strongly localized to regions downstream of large bathymetric features, such as the Kergulean Plateau. Recent work has indicated that turbulent processes near these bathymetric features can cause a rearrangement of the ocean's physical structure on large-scales. As such, these local-scale dynamics may have an influence of the large-scale structure of the global overturning. 

This project aims to blend descriptive and process based approaches to study the influence of "local" dynamics on the "global" overturning. The first stage of the project will use data from satellites, Argo floats, ships and instrumented elephant seals to determine how dynamical processes originating due to flow interaction with large bathymetric features influence the large-scale oceanic structure - in particular the potential vorticity structure and the meridional flux of heat and mass. The second stage of the project will use a high-resolution (eddy-resolving) numerical ocean model, run in an idealized configuration, meant to be representative of the Southern Ocean. The model will be run both with, and without, large-scale bathymetry and with, and without, turbulent eddies. Finally, the output of climate models contained in the CMIP5 database will be examined to determine what influence, if any, the accurate representation of flow/bathymetry interaction in the Southern Ocean has on the response of the global overturning.

por.por_cntn:
The Meridional Overturning Circulation (MOC), a large scale ocean current that acts to redistribute water, heat, nutrients and dissolved gases such as CO2 from the warmer tropics to the colder mid-latitudes and polar regions, is a vital component of the Earth's climate. As such, a solid understanding of the MOC is vital for understanding the climate and its future changes.

 

The goals of this research project is to better understand how the MOC behaves in the Southern Ocean, a region that encircles the Antarctic Continent. The Southern Ocean is host to the world’s strong current system, the Antarctic Circumpolar Current, that acts as a barrier to meridional (north-south) transport. However, when these ACC encounter large, undersea obstacles, strong turbulent eddies are generated that can break this “barrier” effect.

What is the influence of these “local” dynamics of the “global” circulation? How do mixing “barriers” induced by strong ACC jets, and the breaking of the barrier effect by their interaction with undersea bathymetry, modify the MOC? And what is the influence of the regional distribution of sea ice formation and melting this vitally important circulation?

To address the first question, we used a large database of oceanographic observations taken from robotic Argo floats, ship based hydrography and observations taken from instrumented southern elephant seals. Combining the hydrographic observations with observations made by satellites, and using an elegant mathematical theory, we were able to reconstruct, for the first time, the “barrier” effect of the ACC from the surface down to approximately 2000m depth. Using our barrier effect estimates, we are able to estimate the time averaged MOC in the Southern Ocean. When we ignore the barrier effect in our reconstruction of the MOC, we obtain a circulation that is much too strong to be physically realistic. However, when we include the barrier effect, the reconstructed MOC strongly resembles the MOC obtained from high resolution ocean models. As such, we conclude that the barrier effect of the ACC is of vital importance for the formation of MOC. We also find that the southward flux of water is strongly enhanced regions where the ACC interacts with large bathymetric features.

While the previously described estimates of the Southern Ocean MOC were based on a simplified representation of ocean physics. We have also attempted to directly estimate a part of the MOC by using the array of Argo floats as “moving current meters” as they circulate through ocean. To prove that this approach is valid, we performed a “Observation System Simulation Experiment” (OSSE) by simulating the observations taken by Argo floats in a state-of-the-art ocean model. Using the OSSE, we are able to show that the Argo float network is capable of robustly estimating turbulent fluxes of heat and mass, and derive estimates of the errors that can be applied to the real Argo network. We then apply the lessons learned from the OSSE to the real world, where we show that at 1000m depth, around 2Tw of heat are moved south by ocean eddies - with 90% of the total heat flux being concentrated near large bathymetry.    

To further investigate the physics of the overturning and how it is affected by bathymetric features, we have run a highly idealised, yet very high resolution, model of the Southern Ocean - a channel driven by static wind and surface heating/cooling - in four configurations: with and without bottom bathymetry; and with and without turbulent eddies, to disentangle the effects of ocean turbulence and the “bending” of the ACC as it passes over sea-mounts. We find that, when both bathymetry and turbulence is present, its primary effect is breaking the “barrier” induced by the ACC flow. However, even when we “turn-off” the turbulent eddies, the bathymetry still induces a substantial meridional flow, despite the more intact ACC barriers, by strongly tilting density surfaces (isopycnals) towards the surface, which in turn induces a southward flux of mass or heat. In the presence of turbulent eddies, this tilt is more relaxed. Thus, while we have shown that the barrier effect of the ACC is of vital importance for the MOC, it is not the whole story and a subtle interplay between the strength of the barrier and the strength of the isopycnal tilt.

Finally, additional work undertaken in this project has attempted to estimate the deep, turbulent flux of mass and heat from surfaces observations by combining satellite data with data from deep Argo floats using a sophisticated machine learning methodology. This approach yields a performance that it 2 to 3 time better than similar methods. We have also studied the time variability of the ACC currents that are responsible for the “barrier” effect, using satellite data and an advanced statistical method. We find that, in the period 1993-2015, there has been no significant change in their locations or strength.
